Student lobbyists to harrangue congressmen
By A. P. SMITH WICK
Seven hundred students from
all over the country will converge
on George Washington University
Feb. 28—Mar 2 for the National
Student Lobby's second annual
conference. Once registered as
lobbyists, they will spread out
over Capital Hill to argue their
cases personally to Senators and
Congressmens about newsperson's
rights, minimum wage for
students, airline discount fares,
and other issues.
The NSL originated out of the
experience of individuals who
lobbied during the Cambodian
invation in 1970 who recognized
the need and potential to
mobilize students. The
movement expanded from a
strong community program at
Berkley. into the California
Student Lobby and finally into
the NSL.
The major problem of the NSL
itself is money. It is staffed by 15
full time and 5 part time
devotees—interns, recent
graduates and a few professionals.
Their pay barely,covers living
expenses. The primary source of

income is from the 220 member
colleges. Each contributes $50
plus one cent per student. Staff
members hope many more
colleges will join, including
Hopkins.
The NSL decides what issues
to focus on by initiating student
referendums. The top ten issues
are then chosen. A few of the
staff professed that they become
better informed than their
Congressman on these particular.
issues since Congressmen must
devote.their attention to such a
wide range of issues.
The most fashionable issue
today is the protection of
newsperson's rights. 37 bills are
being proposed in Congress, yet
many of these are qualified by
such clauses as "forced disclosure
to federal authorities is
permissible when then the
information is (1) relevant to a
specific crime, (2) unobtainable.
by other means, (3) of
compelling and overiding
national interest."
The NSL is pushing for
unqualified protection. Sen. Alan
Cranston (D-Calif.) has.

introduced such a bill. He said it
would "extend news protection
to the state and local levels where
most of the controversy has
arisen." Today only 17 states
have such "shield laws" for
newspersons.
The NSL is also lobbying for
descriminatory youth fare
discounts, while simultaneously
lobbying against the McDonald's
backed discriminatory
sub-minimum wage bill. It
appears that students want to be
discriminated against in order to
pay less, but treated as adults in
order to be paid the same.
In December the Civil
Aeronautics Board voted to
abolish youth and family air
fares, ruling that they were
discriminatory and unreasonable.
But it hasn't set a date for the
ban. First it must determine
whether all regular fares should
be adjusted to reflect the savings
of the airlines in the absence of
youth fares.
The NSL is lobbying to
reinstate standby discounts for
youth fare and to introduce it for
the elderly. It has made some

headway in this effort.
Congressman Harley Staggers
(D— W. Va.), Chairman of the
House Interstate and Foreign
Commerce Committee had been
hostile to youth and elderly
discounts. According to Rob
Simmons, Community Director
of the NSL, the NSL initiated
efforts to pressure Staggers
through West Virginian
students—a large percentage of
his constituency. West Virginia
students mailed telegrams and
letters. Then the NSL "picked up
the ball," said Simmons, and
spoke with Staggers. He is now
introducing the bill himself.
McDonald's is known as the
main culprit lobbying f6r a 20%
lower minimum wage for youth.
McDonald's contributed
$255,000 to re-elect Nixon and
backed a sub-minimum wage bill
last May that passed the House
but not the Senate.
Congressman John Erlenbom
(R—Ill.) has introduced basically
the same bill whereby a student
under 21 or a non-student under
18 could be hired for S1.60 per
hoir instead of $2.10 per hour.

Student lobbyists to harrangue congressmen
By A. P. SMITH WICK
Seven hundred students from
all over the country will converge
on George Washington University
Feb. 28—Mar 2 for the National
Student Lobby's second annual
conference. Once registered as
lobbyists, they will spread out
over Capital Hill to argue their
cases personally to Senators and
Congressmens about newsperson's
rights, minimum wage for
students, airline discount fares,
and other issues.
The NSL originated out of the
experience of individuals who
lobbied during the Cambodian
invation in 1970 who recognized
the need and potential to
mobilize students. The
movement expanded from a
strong community program at
Berkley. into the California
Student Lobby and finally into
the NSL.
The major problem of the NSL
itself is money. It is staffed by 15
full time and 5 part time
devotees—interns, recent
graduates and a few professionals.
Their pay barely,covers living
expenses. The primary source of

income is from the 220 member
colleges. Each contributes $50
plus one cent per student. Staff
members hope many more
colleges will join, including
Hopkins.
The NSL decides what issues
to focus on by initiating student
referendums. The top ten issues
are then chosen. A few of the
staff professed that they become
better informed than their
Congressman on these particular.
issues since Congressmen must
devote.their attention to such a
wide range of issues.
The most fashionable issue
today is the protection of
newsperson's rights. 37 bills are
being proposed in Congress, yet
many of these are qualified by
such clauses as "forced disclosure
to federal authorities is
permissible when then the
information is (1) relevant to a
specific crime, (2) unobtainable.
by other means, (3) of
compelling and overiding
national interest."
The NSL is pushing for
unqualified protection. Sen. Alan
Cranston (D-Calif.) has.

introduced such a bill. He said it
would "extend news protection
to the state and local levels where
most of the controversy has
arisen." Today only 17 states
have such "shield laws" for
newspersons.
The NSL is also lobbying for
descriminatory youth fare
discounts, while simultaneously
lobbying against the McDonald's
backed discriminatory
sub-minimum wage bill. It
appears that students want to be
discriminated against in order to
pay less, but treated as adults in
order to be paid the same.
In December the Civil
Aeronautics Board voted to
abolish youth and family air
fares, ruling that they were
discriminatory and unreasonable.
But it hasn't set a date for the
ban. First it must determine
whether all regular fares should
be adjusted to reflect the savings
of the airlines in the absence of
youth fares.
The NSL is lobbying to
reinstate standby discounts for
youth fare and to introduce it for
the elderly. It has made some

headway in this effort.
Congressman Harley Staggers
(D— W. Va.), Chairman of the
House Interstate and Foreign
Commerce Committee had been
hostile to youth and elderly
discounts. According to Rob
Simmons, Community Director
of the NSL, the NSL initiated
efforts to pressure Staggers
through West Virginian
students—a large percentage of
his constituency. West Virginia
students mailed telegrams and
letters. Then the NSL "picked up
the ball," said Simmons, and
spoke with Staggers. He is now
introducing the bill himself.
McDonald's is known as the
main culprit lobbying f6r a 20%
lower minimum wage for youth.

$255,000 to re-elect Nixon and

last May that passed the House
but not the Senate.

(R—Ill.) has introduced basically
the same bill whereby a student

18 could be hired for S1.60 per
hoir instead of $2.10 per hour.
